title: About
text:
Hello üëãüèæ and welcome to shokunin!
My name is Damilare (a.k.a Dami) and I‚Äôm currently a research analyst (who really does analysis engineering) @ a do-tank that tests, scales, and implements promising solutions to urban problems. I am an economist by training, a programmer by accident, and a data scientist at heart.
I‚Äôve heard data scientists described as people who are better statisticians than most software engineers and better software engineers than most statisticians, and I‚Äôve never felt more seen üòÇ.
I am an avid reader üìö, gamer üéÆ, learner üî¨ and tinkerer üîß.
shokunin1 is my data-science and machine-learning blog where I leverage my interest in learning, writing, programming, and popular culture to irreverently pursue continued improvement in my craft.

If you‚Äôre curious about my blog‚Äôs name, check this post‚Ü©Ô∏é

title: Ideas
text:
Photo by Patrick Tomasso on Unsplash
In a previous post I discussed keeping running lists of resources I want to come back to. In addition to these, I‚Äôve decided to also keep a list of future ideas for shokunin. Although I initially balked at the idea of posting my unfinished plans, I really do want shokunin to be a ‚Äúplace‚Äù where I can cultivate, refine, and share my interconnected thoughts and ideas.1 While I think I can cultivate and share my musings already, I think showing the process of refining an initial idea can only be done by showing different ideas at different stages of development. Additionally, I think keeping a list of future ideas can also act as an easy commitment device2.
So consider my list of future ideas an informal contract/promise about what‚Äôs likely coming up for shokunin. That said, I make absolutely no promises about the quality and tidyness of those ideas. What I do promise is that the idea at the very top will always be those I‚Äôm currently spending the most time working on.
Dedicated to craft,
Dami

title: Straight Outta Brooklyn
text:
I decided to make a blog!
For quite a while I‚Äôve been feeling stuck in my career and unsure about how to demonstrate and build my data-science skills. All the advice I‚Äôve heard (and read) can be boiled down into variations of ‚Äúdo a personal project!!‚Äù. Macklin Flusher has this fantastic article about modern job searching. The article is worth a full read, but the TLDR is this:
Well, I finally decided to follow Macklin‚Äôs advice (more on that later üòâ), but then (because I can‚Äôt resist using one goal to achieve other goals ü§¶üèæ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è) I decided to also build a blog to host that project.
But wait, what‚Äôs a blog? ü§î
A blog is just a website with a reverse chronological order (newer content appears first) that can be indexed and syndicated on RSS feeds. Whereas many website pages are pretty static, because they are updated so frequently, blogs tend to be very dynamic.
But wait, why a blog? üßê
I‚Äôve created a blog because I want to:
So, to summarize, I‚Äôm hoping to create a digital garden that helps me build a brand, shore up what I‚Äôm learning, and centralize information ‚Ä¶¬† Sounds easy enough?! üò´
So, welcome to my blog shokunin ‚Ä¶ straight outta brooklyn.
Dedicated to Craft,
Dami

title: Keeping Lists
text:
To list or not to list‚Ä¶
I‚Äôve decided to keep a running list of things I want to come back to. Right now this is primarily going to contain articles, books, and videos broken down by whether they apply more to my work or personal lives.

I update prices to reflect new MTA pricing
I account for inflation to reflect how time has passed

Title: That‚Äôs slower than I thought!
Subtitle: On doing one successful thing too many times
Starting Quote: The way you‚Äôd do something once is rarely the best way to do it 1000x - Quote from David Robinson
Inspiring article: Making R Code Faster: A Case Study
Idea: Driven by a situation at work where I‚Äôd written code that did something correctly once and then just attempted to map that code. Although it took a while. I came back to the repo ran it and was shocked that it ran much quicker than before. Turns out a senior colleague had changed one line (shown below). This is an attempt to figure out why it was so fast.

Title: The condition of man‚Ä¶ is a condition of war of everyone against everyone
Subtitle: On taking care about how you define conditions
Idea: I was recently working on unit testing an API package and I could not get a unit test to pass despite modifying the function that was being tested and being absolutely sure the error message I expected was the one that was being thrown. Turns out that although the messages ‚Äúlooked‚Äù the same to the human eye, there was some regex weirdness happening.

title: Dedication to Craft
text:
‚ÄúAll I want to do is make better sushi ‚Ä¶ I do the same thing over and over improving bit by bit. There is always a yearning to achieve more ‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve achieved perfection. But I feel ecstatic all day. I love making sushi. That‚Äôs the spirit of the Shokunin‚Äù






Photo by Airam Dato-on on Unsplash


I first came across the term ‚Äôshokunin‚Äô while watching Midnight Asia ‚Äî a Netflix docuseries about the nightlife of six east asian cities. In the Tokyo episode, we meet Rogerio, co-founder of one of Asia‚Äôs 50 best bars, who shares a profound insight: ‚ÄúTo master your craft, you need to master yourself. In Japan there is a strong culture of shokunin ‚Ä¶ a person that is always pursuing to better his craft‚Äù.
Shokunin describes an orientation to work that emphasizes dedication to craft through exceptional technical skill and an unwavering quest for mastery. Jiro Ono, the star of ‚ÄòJiro Dreams of Sushi‚Äô and already a sushi master by every conventional standard, stands out and continues to passionately refine his craft because his aspiration is excellence itself.¬†
I‚Äôve chosen to name this blog ‚Äòshokunin‚Äô to reflect my desire to apply this philosophy to the data science and machine learning work I share here. I want to build exceptional technical skills and pursue continual improvement in my craft and I‚Äôd be thrilled if you joined me for the ride.
Dedicated to craft,
Dami

title: Analysis Engineering
text:
Photo by ThisisEngineering RAEng on Unsplash
I‚Äôve been working on a post about how I built my DS/ML blog, but I‚Äôm a perfectionist (and I‚Äôm new to this) so it‚Äôs taking me some time to write a post I‚Äôm happy with. That said, I do want to build a habit of posting regularly, so I decided to do a ‚Äúshorter‚Äù piece on something I think about a lot ‚Ä¶ my job title.
